DataElement.preferredName: Miller and Payne Malignant Neoplasm Response Classification Grade
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Grade from a classification system that includes the primary tumor and the status of the axillary lymph nodes (ALN), with comparison of negative nodes with those that have already responded to therapy.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to disease event response.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Event; something that happens at a given place and time.:A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Something that happens at a given place and time.

Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredDefinition: Response; a bodily process occurring due to the effect of some foregoing stimulus or agent.

Concepts.definition: Any act or phenomena, or behavior, constituting a reply or reaction of a living organism or its part to some foregoing stimulus or agent.

Property.changeDescription: Denise Warzel updated Definition by seraching NCI Thesaurus in Admin tool.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Miller and Payne Malignant Neoplasm Response Classification Grade
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Miller and Payne grading scale for pathological responses, combining primary tumor and axillary lymph nodes in grading a pathological remission status.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Some alteration to individual malignant cells but no reduction in overall number

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Some alteration to individual malignant cells but no reduction in overall number
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Some alteration to individual malignant cells but no reduction in overall number

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Minor loss of invasive tumor cells but overall cellularity still high

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Minor loss of invasive tumor cells but overall cellularity still high
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Minor loss of invasive tumor cells but overall cellularity still high

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Moderate reduction in tumor cells up to an estimated 90% loss

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Moderate reduction in tumor cells up to an estimated 90% loss
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Moderate reduction in tumor cells up to an estimated 90% loss

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Marked disappearance of invasive tumor cells such that only small clusters of widely dispersed cells detected

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Marked disappearance of invasive tumor cells such that only small clusters of widely dispersed cells detected
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked disappearance of invasive tumor cells such that only small clusters of widely dispersed cells detected

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: No invasive cells identifiable in sections from the site of the previous tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: No invasive cells identifiable in sections from the site of the previous tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No invasive cells identifiable in sections from the site of the previous tumor

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:In medicine, an improvement related to treatment.:A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.:A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.
A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
